extent.note: Volume: I + 76 + I sheets. Text content: pp. 1v to 76r. Format: 245 153.

foliation.p: Originally without pagination. Simple page counting on the recto of each written folio (1-76) added manually in the upper right corner by a later editor/librarian.

collation.p: A hardback codex with wooden covers, apparently - as typical of the period - coated with undyed leather, thas has darkened over the centuries. (Autopsy needed.)
Quire binding: Quires sewn on three double-bunches of hemp strings? (Autopsy needed.)

condition.p: Very well-preserved manuscript without lacunae in the contained text. Numerous stains, in places also abrasions within the text (partially resulting in unreadable or missing letters) and undulations of the parchment. Sporadically bent page corners ("dog ears"). Several times cracks/fissures on one of the margins (fol. 1, 6, 7, 8, 11, 12, 27, 41, 42, 46, 53, 67, 74, 75), but only in individual places a veritable tear (fol. 50) or a hole in the sheet (fol. 7, 46).

layout.p: All texts written down in a single, fairly regular text block (a single "column"). However, within the Gesta Francorum, the Descriptio sanctorum locorum Hierusalem, and the Missa in ueneratione Sancti Sepulchri, all written by the same hand, there have been frequently extended beyond the beginning of a line (in the form of a hanging indent) and highlighted in red colour the first letter of a new sentence as well as the initials at the beginning of a new book. Occasional extension of a word either into the margin area (a singular exception, however, the significant transgression of the text block on fol. 40r, lines 16f.), or above the first or beyond the last line of a page.

In the main parts of the manuscript (that is, irrespective of the additional verses on fol. 68r and fol. 76r), varying number of lines per page: (a) for the Gesta Francorum, the Descriptio sanctorum locorum Hierusalem and the Missa in ueneratione Sancti Sepulchri between 22 and 26 lines, (b) for the letter of the Paderborn-/Cologne-based scholasticist Oliver between 28 and 31 lines (apart from the concluding fol. 76r with 8 lines). - Synopsis of the distribution of the number of lines: (a) 22 lines: fol. 1v-8v; 23 lines: fol. 33r-v, 40r-v; 24 lines: 9r-10v, 15r-23v, 34r-39v, 41r-67r; 25 lines: fol. 11v-14v; 26 lines: fol 11r. - (b) 28 lines: fol. 69r; 29 lines: fol. 69v, 70r, 73v, 74r; 30 lines: fol. 71v-73r, 74v, 75r; 31 lines: fol. 70v, 71r, 75v.
Stamp of the Bibliotheca Apostolica Vaticana: a) on fol. 1r in the bottom center; and b) on fol. 76v around the center, slightly shifted to the left.

handNote.p: (1.) Text of the Gesta Francorum et aliorum Hierosolimitanorum, the Descriptio sanctorum locorum Hierusalem, and the Missa in ueneratione Sancti Sepulchri: written by a single hand in a variant of the Carolingian Minuscule already revealing in its execution characteristics of a Praegothica / Romano-Gothica (vertical extension, shapes of letter shafts and curves, breaking of lines, serifs, ornamental edges, and more) (cf. for the development of high medieval book-scripts the overview by Fingernagel (2007)); dating back probably to the early 12th century; very accurate and regular writing.
(2.) The panegyrical verses on Bohemond of Taranto: written by one or several hands in a Gothic Textura, the first eight lines in a fairly accurate writing.
(3.) The letter of the Paderborn-/Cologne-based scholasticist Oliver: written by a single hand in a Gothic Textura; dating back probably to the 13th century; very accurate and regular writing.
(4.) The verses added to Oliver's letter: written by a single hand in a Gothic Cursive, a smoothly executed informal type, evidently less elaborated than the writing of the preceding texts.

decoDesc.p: All texts written down in a dark brown ink, probably an iron gall ink (widely used in Europe during the High Middle Ages). Highlighting of the title, of marked book transitions (= Explicit and Incipit notes up to book IV), of the initials of each book and of the first letters of a sentence in red colour. Furthermore, regularly executed in red colour decorative elements in places of transgressions above or beyond a line and of additions / corrections (fol. 1v, 3r, 4r, 6v, 11v, 12v, 16r, 18v, 20v, 22v, 28r, 32r, 35v, 44v, 50v, 51r, 55v, 58r, 62v, 66v). On fol. 67r two broad lines executed in red colour as a reference scale (deduced from the Holy Sepulchre) for the body measurements of Jesus Christ. Apart from this no further illustrations.

history.p: The "Codex Vaticanus Reginensis latinus 572", usually referred to by the abbreviation "Reg. lat. 572", has been bound together in its extant form - unfortunately, there is a complete lack of information concerning its early history - presumably in the Late Middle Ages. The volume contains different components regarding age and provenance. The text of the Gesta Francorum et aliorum Hierosolimitanorum and, attached to it, the Descriptio sanctorum locorum Hierusalem as well as the Missa in ueneratione Sancti Sepulchri have according to palaeographical analysis and matching historical and philological evidence probably been written in the early 12th century in Norman France. From the 13th century dates, by contrast, the copy of a highly elaborated letter added to the convolute, written by the Paderborn-/Cologne-based scholasticist Oliver (Thomas Olivier) on the occasion of the siege of the Egyptian port city of Damietta (1219) during the Fifth Crusade. (From the same or from a later period originate the verses on fol. 68r and fol. 76r of the manuscript, supplemented by further hands.) The question, however, when exactly and for what reasons these (at least thematically related) main components have been united in a single codex - perhaps (as suggested by other manuscripts with a similar structure) for the purpose of contemporary crusade sermons? -, cannot be answered satisfyingly at the present state of knowledge. At any rate, in the state described before the codex later passed into the ownership of the French scholar, antiquary and book collector Paul Pétau (1568-1614) (cf. the note on fol. 69r, added by a later hand: ex bibliotheca Pauli Petauij Senatoris) and thereafter into the personal library of Christina of Sweden (1626-1689, Swedish Queen 1632-1654), who after her conversion to Catholicism (and the loss of her crown) had moved to Rome. After her death in 1689, her library fell into the hands of her former protector, cardinal Decio Azzolini (the Younger: 1623-1689), and was transferred by him to his nephew Pompejo Azzolini. Out of the possession of this man it was acquired in 1690 for pope Alexander VIII. (Pietro Vito Ottoboni: 1610-1691, elected pope in 1689) and integrated into the holdings of the Bibliotheca Apostolica Vaticana. In this place, the Latin manuscripts once taken over from the Swedish queen - including the "Reginensis latinus 572" - are to be found in the famous collection of the "Vaticani latini". As a result of a major project launched in 2010, aimed at the complete digitalization of the library's manuscript holdings, not least the "Reg. lat. 572" is already accessible on the web portal of the "Digital Vatican Library" (DigiVatLib) (see https://digi.vatlib.it/view/MSS_Reg.lat.572).
List of references: Bethmann (1874), 294; Bréhier (1924), XXIIff.; Buonocore (1995), 31f.; Hagenmeyer (1890), 95; Hill/Mynors (1962), XXXVIIIf.

encodingDesc.p: Synopsis of the special characters / glyphs used in the text

Set out below are letter variants, diacritics and special characters that have been used by the scribe of the "Gesta Francorum" text presented here to display the numerous abbreviations in it. Their labels and "code points", encoding-specific number values for a unique referencing (given here in hexadecimal format), are based on the indications and conventions of the Medieval Unicode Font Initiative (MUFI) (cf. https://folk.uib.no/hnooh/mufi/). Yet, in order to cover the text of the manuscript in a manner also palaeographically comprehensible, it was necessary to go beyond the "Character Set" of the current Unicode standard and draw on encoding recommendations from Unicode's so-called "Private Use Area" (PUA) still open to debate, and in specific cases even - faute de mieux - on individual makeshifts of the encoder.

Under these circumstances, for an adequate representation of several of the characters a special font is needed, preferably one of the fonts recommended by the MUFI (cf. especially Andron Scriptor Web, Cardo, Junicode und Palemonas MUFI).

note.p: For the use of the term "Hierosolimitani" see already Bréhier, 1 n. 1: "Au moyen âge, on donnait souvent aux pélerins le nom même du sanctuaire qu'ils étaient allés vénérer."

Xerigordos, a fortress in the surrounding area of Nicaea (cf. Bréhier (1924), 9 n. 4; Runciman (1957), 126f.). The Greek name of the fortress is attested in the Alexias, a large-scale historical epic by the Byzantine author Anna Komnene about the life of her revered father, the emperor Alexios.
